The opposition leader changed his position daily with the numbers in his party room, trying to shore up his leadership. So what we had from the opposition was an incoherent ramble in relation to how they would deal with the global financial crisis, whereas on this side of the House we had a sound, well thought out strategy that took account of the changing nature of the economy and how things would change over time.

In my electorate of Dobell, there are over 673 stimulus package projects, totalling $107 million. We have over 106 projects taking place in schools around my electorate. I had the opportunity of meeting Rob, an apprentice at Tacoma Public School, just the other day. Rob is an example of what this stimulus package is about. He is a fourth-year apprentice carpenter who had not worked for six months and whose apprenticeship was in danger of falling over. Because of the stimulus package, he now has a job and his apprenticeship is going to be completed. That is good on two fronts: (1) because it means that this young fellow has a job and is contributing to the economy and (2) because it means that his skills will be used as we come out of this global recession.
This is a nation-building stimulus, a stimulus that meets the requirements of the crisis that this country faced. It is something that all members of this place should be supporting.

subdebateinfo.title: Cowan Electorate: Girrawheen Senior High School

talk.start.para: —There are many schools in the electorate of Cowan, and they do great work. On Friday night I attended a dance performance at Girrawheen Senior High School. The Special Dance program is a key curriculum initiative for the school. On the night, there were many routines involving groups of up to 25 dancers and two solo dance performances from year 12 students. A strong crowd of several hundred friends and family members joined with staff to enjoy an excellent show, Girra-Mix. I congratulate all the students but also make mention of award winners: in year 12, Catherine Barnes for dance practical and Jessika Leadbitter for dance theory; in year 8, Emily Edwards, dancer of the year, and Paige Sims, dancer to watch; in year 9, Deanne Straw and Dbada Salih; in year l0, Shae Hazzard and Wendy Ha; and, in year 11, Azlina Asmad and Angela Williams. The Special Dance program, under the leadership of Miss Pamela Konijn, demonstrated that such programs are vital not only in connecting young people to education itself but in helping them to develop a strong work and study ethic as well as the responsibility of working as a member of a team.

speech.para: In speaking with the Director Schools of the Department of Education and Training’s West Coast Education District, David Lee, I got a better appreciation of not only his confidence in the staff at Girrawheen but also the sense of dedication the staff have to their students. Certainly I appreciate that the socioeconomic circumstances and the diversity of the area create challenges, but those challenges are being met via a staff profile and the resources to meet the needs. An important statistic is that close to 40 per cent of parents of students at the school were born overseas, so it is little wonder the school holds up diversity as a strength and is at the centre of many multicultural activities in the district.

Students come to Girrawheen Senior High School from Girrawheen, Koondoola, Marangaroo and Alexander Heights. Whilst at the dance performance I also saw Tina Darling, whom I know as the President of the Marangaroo Primary School P&C but who is also the head of the Girrawheen Senior High School Council. Tina is one of the many local people committed to the success of Girrawheen Senior High School.

The school provides opportunities for university entrance, trade and training qualifications, and other forms of training and pathways to employment. I have had significant contact with Noel Woodley, the principal, regarding a number of local issues, and it is clear that the leadership is taking the school in the right direction. I have met the deputies, Ann Southwell and, on Friday night, Barbara Newton. I have also met a number of staff members and have been impressed by their commitment and drive.

Whenever I am in Girrawheen, which is every day that I am in Cowan, I see the great potential of the area. That potential is clearest when you see the children and young people who live there and in the surrounding suburbs. The state schools in Girrawheen—Hudson Park and Roseworth Primary Schools and Girrawheen Senior High School—offer educational pathways to a good future, and that future is without limitations. What I would say to the people, and particularly the young people, in Girrawheen is that you should have a dream, a dream that you can and will achieve a solid future for yourself. This has nothing to do with luck, and it should not involve waiting for someone to deliver any special benefits to individuals. Through the schools in Girrawheen our young people have access to opportunities, and they should embrace them. No young person should absent themselves from school and no parent or care provider should have anything but a full commitment to ensuring an education for young people. Indeed, by example, those parents and carers should lead the young towards the strongest commitment to education and the opportunity for gainful employment that is directly linked to that very education.

Literacy and numeracy are the core building blocks for education. As shown by the recent NAPLAN results, Girrawheen Senior High School has achieved outstanding success in literacy and numeracy. The school operates courses in English as a second language as well as the ITAS, or Indigenous Tutorial Assistance Scheme—all building on literacy and numeracy and providing opportunities for long-term individual success. From these programs and the vocational opportunities provided at Girrawheen Senior High School, the students have achieved success, including tertiary entrance and access to training—Certificate II in Building and Construction—and employment, as well as improved literacy and numeracy outcomes. The programs are there, and the results are there. Beyond the mainstream support, as individually focused as it is, the school has an education support unit and a program for students at educational risk as well as initiatives for talented and gifted students.

I say again that Girrawheen Senior High School is a school that provides excellent opportunities for its students. The leaders and the teachers do a very good job, and I offer them my thanks and appreciation for the work they do. This is the first time that the school has ever been mentioned as the subject of a speech. Given the great work that Girrawheen Senior High School does, I think it is long overdue.

talk.start.para: —Recently I was presented with a petition on homelessness in the Ballarat region. The petition was gathered by the social justice ministry of the Our Lady Help of Christians in Wendouree. This committee has done a terrific job in collecting 140 signatures from residents who are concerned about the level of homelessness in our region. The signatures from members across the Wendouree community are from residents who are seeking further action on the homelessness crisis.

speech.para: It is with an increasing sense of unease that we, a nation of prosperity and wealth, have witnessed a growing number of homeless over recent decades. The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare produced a report on Victoria’s homeless from the 2006 census. The Counting the Homeless report found the rate of homeless in Ballarat was 47 per 10,000, compared with 29 per 10,000 in Geelong and 37 per 10,000 in Warrnambool. This equated to 399 homeless people in Ballarat.

No Australians should find themselves forced into homelessness. It is, frankly, unacceptable. The Rudd government has put this issue at the forefront of the public agenda. Following our white paper on homelessness the federal government released a national plan on reducing homelessness by 2020. We have committed to halving the rate of homelessness by that time. This is a crucial target and we must meet this objective. The white paper, The Road Home, outlined a number of important steps in our approach to achieving this target. One of the overarching messages in this report was the importance of the entire community accepting and taking responsibility for our nation’s homeless. Since being elected we have seen a dramatic boost in funding towards the homeless. As part of the nation-building economic stimulus plan the Rudd government is investing $5.7 billion in social housing. The social housing program will deliver over 19,000 new homes, with the assistance of the not-for-profit sector, and refurbish more than 60,000 existing properties. Over 10,000 of the repaired homes would have been lost to stock within two years were it not for the Rudd government’s investment.

Across my electorate of Ballarat we have seen a number of announcements. At present the Ballarat electorate has seen 65 social housing dwellings approved, to the tune of $14.2 million. Additionally we are undertaking the repair and maintenance of a number of dwellings across the region. The funding provided for social housing under the Nation Building and Jobs Plan aims to reduce the public housing waiting list and reduce homelessness across the region.

The Rudd government is also delivering on its election commitment with the implementation of the National Rental Affordability Scheme, now well underway. The Ballarat electorate is seeing a significant surge in affordable rental housing with the approval of 119 homes. Rent for these properties is charged at 20 per cent below the market rate for eligible recipients. This is great news for families in the region that are struggling to pay their bills. The National Rental Affordability Scheme is contributing to affordable housing being built in Wendouree, Soldiers Hill, Golden Point, Sebastopol, Mount Pleasant, Brown Hill, Canadian and Delacombe. Two areas that will see a significant growth in affordable private rental housing include Sebastopol, with 24 homes being built, and Bacchus Marsh, with 78 homes being built.

Only a few weeks ago I visited a family in Bacchus Marsh who are now living in a new home built as part of the National Rental Affordability Scheme. Julia and their three boys moved in a few weeks ago now. Tanya Plibersek and I were absolutely delighted to meet with that family and see that having that rental accommodation provided at that rate was providing them an opportunity to, at some point, regain a foot into the housing market themselves. The Minister for Housing, Tanya Plibersek, and I were delighted to visit the region and discuss the importance and value of the initiative to families. It is a perfect example of the impact the Rudd government’s program is having on electorates around the nation.

In our nation’s era of relative prosperity, we have an opportunity to bring about real change to those in our community who need it most. It is a wonderful tribute to the Wendouree community that they have come together to speak out on this important issue. I take their concerns seriously. This is a serious issue. I look forward to working with all communities, including those involved with this petition, as we move towards achieving our 2020 targets. I seek leave to table the petition.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —The document will be forwarded to the Standing Committee on Petitions for its consideration. It will be accepted subject to confirmation by the committee that it conforms to the standing orders.

—I would like to highlight one man’s quest for justice from the Department of Veterans’ Affairs. My constituent had joined the New Zealand Navy as a young lad in 1955. About 10 years later the Australian Navy was short of engineers and the New Zealand Navy was short of electricians. It had been usual practice for servicemen from across the Tasman to be ‘loaned’ to various services. This plan was to have four New Zealanders join the Australian Navy and four Australians join the New Zealand Navy. My constituent, Robert Wilson, is not sure what happened to the Australians moving to New Zealand. However, he was one of four New Zealanders who packed their bags and moved to Australia.

speech.para: Mr Wilson and his wife flew to Sydney on 7 July 1966. They were accommodated at the Royal Naval House—known as ‘Johnnies’. Of the four New Zealanders who travelled to Australia, two were married and two were single. Mr Wilson and the other married New Zealander and his wife were accommodated at Johnnies. Both men took the oath of allegiance and a couple of days later were drafted onto HMAS Kuttabul. They were both posted to HMAS Vampire and sailed for the Far East Strategic Reserve in January 1967. The two single New Zealanders also arrived in Australia at this time, one being posted to Melbourne and the other to HMAS Kuttabul.

Mr Wilson and his mate were given identical postings on HMAS Vampire. During this time HMAS Vampire escorted HMAS Sydney to Vietnam, ferrying personnel and supplies. The ship and her personnel were also deployed to Hong Kong to evacuate Australian Embassy staff due to civil unrest in that area. Both men were then drafted back to HMAS Kuttabul Fleet Maintenance Unit in 1967. Both families then moved back to New Zealand in June 1968 to complete their New Zealand service. Mr Wilson, his Australian-born wife and his family migrated to Australia following the completion of his service. He became an Australian citizen in 1991.

Upon reaching the age of 70, Mr Wilson contacted his workmate, who is also living in Australia now, and he confirmed that his mate had qualified for a gold card. So Mr Wilson lodged an application for a gold card, but it was rejected. He had, in the department’s words, ‘rendered qualifying service’ but in their eyes he was ‘not a member of the forces of a Commonwealth or allied country, who was domiciled in Australia or an external Territory immediately before enlistment in those forces’. Mr Wilson again rang his mate in Tasmania and was assured that his mate’s application was approved. Mr Wilson came to me, his local member, and I made representations to the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, to no avail. The minister pointed to privacy restrictions preventing the checking on his mate’s eligibility and the legitimacy of his entitlement. The minister also advised that:

quote.para: … it is not uncommon to have people in similar circumstances granted different eligibilities due to variations in their service particulars.

speech.para: When two men, with their wives, move to Australia to serve with the RAN and then serve on the same ships and finish their service in New Zealand I cannot see why the minister cannot check the records to see why one man receives a gold card and the other does not. If the cases are different then the department should be able to confirm that this is so without hiding behind privacy laws; otherwise justice is not served in this case. Mr Wilson advises me also that one of the single men who came over at the time has been granted a gold card.

I call on the minister not to hide behind so-called privacy issues and to examine both cases on their merits and advise me why two servicemen with the same service records should not both have a gold card or the same entitlement. I implore the minister to invoke the commonsense rule and apply it to this case. Having myself been a minister and a chief of staff to the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, I know how difficult it is for the bureaucracy to admit to a mistake and eat humble pie. On this occasion I believe it is warranted.

talk.start.para: —Last Sunday, 18 October, I had the great pleasure of being invited to attend the launch on Sunday night of the seventh national Greek Welfare Conference, which was held in Adelaide in South Australia. I was very honoured to have been invited and to have attended.

speech.para: At the dinner on Sunday night His Grace Bishop Nikandros of Doryleon was there as the South Australian Greek Orthodox Bishop. He was there representing His Eminence Archbishop Stylianos of Australia, who is the head of the Greek Orthodox Church in Australia. Also, state member Tom Koutsantonis was there representing the Premier. The guest speaker for the night was Monsignor David Cappo, who is the Commissioner for Social Inclusion in South Australia. He spoke to all those in attendance about those who are alienated in our communities and less fortunate and what we can do to help and assist. Also in attendance were Mr John Kiasoglous, the chairman of the Ethnic Schools Board, and Mrs Maria Paltoglou, who is very active, especially in my electorate of Hindmarsh. Mrs Paltoglou is the vice-president of the ladies auxiliary and does a lot of good work—a lot of volunteer work—in my electorate. Also in attendance was Father Patsouris, who is the priest of our local parish of the Greek Orthodox Church at St George in Mile End.

The reason we were all there was to acknowledge the fantastic and dedicated efforts by all those associated with the Greek Welfare Centre. It was great to host the national conference in Adelaide on the weekend, and I believe it is still going on and will finish tomorrow.

The Greek Welfare Centre was established by the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of Australia as a means of providing assistance to migrant ethnic groups. It does everything from assisting the homeless to helping those who are less fortunate, and it even offers an interpreting service. It does very important work, especially in times like this when the economy is very difficult for people. That is why the Greek Welfare Centre is very important in assisting disadvantaged people in the community. It also has such services as ‘meals on wheels’, which is a fantastic service offering home delivered meals. I am sure that the member for Parkes, who co-chairs with me the group that we formed here in Parliament House for meals on wheels, would agree with me. They do magnificent work and in this case it is really important because a lot of the people in the ethnic communities will perhaps lose their command of the English language as they get older. It is important that they have people making contact with them every day through the home delivery service, which ensures that they are having meals catered for and tailored to their needs. It is therefore a very important service.

They also offer information and referral services for a variety of government and non-government departments and other mainstream departments. They offer the services of community education and health education. They have a strong passion. They have already established a mental health team to do research and to assist those in our community who suffer from mental-related illness and disabilities.

I am also pleased to learn that the Greek Welfare Centre have recently added a youth program focusing on disadvantaged youth within the community. One of my staff has been assisting them along the way. This is a very important service because, as all of us in this place would agree, youth are our future. This was acknowledged on Sunday night in the future visions and aspirations of the Greek Welfare Centre.

So much time and effort and hard work have been put into the Greek Welfare Centre to place it in the position it is in today. But, of course, that future depends on the availability of volunteers, and I would like to acknowledge all of the volunteers who are giving their time to help the Greek Welfare Centre. We all know the benefits and tremendous outcomes of our goals, but it is only due to the assistance of those wonderful volunteers.

The Greek Welfare Centre is a great organisation. It offers many services and will even assist people to adapt into the Australian community. The Greek Welfare Centre should therefore be very proud of the tireless contribution by the many members of the large Greek community who play a role in all of the individual associations involved in the centre.

Once again I would like to congratulate the board of management and all the employees and volunteers of the Greek Welfare Centre. I wish them the very best in their ever-evolving plans for the centre’s direction. Again, I congratulate them for their tireless contribution to the community.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 9 pm, the debate is interrupted.
—to present a bill for an act to amend the Fair Work Act 2009, and for related purposes.

—to present a bill for an act to amend the Native Title Act 1993, and for related purposes.
—to present a bill for an act to deal with consequential matters arising from the enactment of the Personal Property Securities Act 2009, to amend that act, and for related purposes.
—to move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with section 10B of the Health Insurance Act 1973, the House approves the Health Insurance (Extended Medicare Safety Net) Determination 2009 made on 9 October 2009, and presented to the House on 19 October 2009.

talk.start.para: —to move:

motion.para: That the House:

item.label: (a)
item.para: building community infrastructure or improving community amenity has the potential to generate local jobs and increase skills and social capital;

item.label: (b)
item.para: investment in cycling is regarded as a cost effective way to increase mobility and physical activity levels, make recreation accessible and boost regional tourism; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: small shifts in transport modes to other forms, such as cycling, may provide substantial dividends and important benefits for the transport and freight sector and reduce congestion, increase efficiency and lower greenhouse gas emissions; and
supports:

item.label: (a)

item.label: (b)

item.label: (c)

talk.start.para: —to move:

motion.para: That the House:

item.para: notes the widespread calls from throughout the community to provide more clarity with respect to Australian food labelling standards;
acknowledges progress made to date in ensuring that Australian food labelling laws provide consumers with the relevant and clear information that they require to make informed product choices;
notes that Australian producers and consumers will benefit from clearer food labelling laws and that there are economic and health outcomes related to this matter;
acknowledges the importance of this matter to both Australian producers and consumers; and

notes and supports the review being undertaken by the Australian and New Zealand Food Regulation Ministerial Council and asks the Minister for Health and Ageing to consider any options available to speed up the review process.

talk.start.para: —to move:

motion.para: That the House:

item.para: notes the impact of homelessness on individuals and families around Australia;
acknowledges the strategies of the Rudd Government in addressing affordable housing and homelessness;
recognises the important work of not‑for‑profit and other community‑based organisations in tackling homelessness; and
congratulates the Nepean Campaign Against Homelessness on the launch of its Regional Taskforce and the work that it has been doing to improve access to affordable housing.

talk.start.para: —to move:

motion.para: That the House:

item.para: recognises that the Australian live export industry:

item.label: (a)
item.para: employs 13,000 Australians nationally across 30 separate business types;

item.label: (b)
item.para: contributes AUD$1.8 billion each year to Australia’s Gross Domestic Product;

item.label: (c)
item.para: pays AUD$987 million a year in wages and salaries; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: contributes AUD$830 million to regional economies and underpins the economic and social wellbeing of large slices of rural and remote Australia, particularly in Western Australia;
notes that:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Australia is regarded as the world leader in livestock export regulation and management;

item.label: (b)
item.para: if Australia stopped live export, the trade would go to less scrupulous countries than ours and put severe supply pressure on already struggling third world countries;

item.label: (c)
item.para: it would cost the Australian economy AUD$1 billion to phase out live trade;

item.label: (d)
item.para: the cessation of live export would have a severe impact on domestic markets, particularly in the regions;

item.label: (e)
item.para: many pastoralists in the electoral division of Kalgoorlie do not have the option to crop as an alternative industry as suggested by the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) commissioned ACIL Tasman report; and

item.label: (f)
item.para: the RSPCA and People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) should focus on real and relevant animal cruelty issues; and
considers that the Australian Government should commit to a campaign countering RSPCA and PETA misinformation.

talk.start.para: —to move:

motion.para: That the House acknowledges the Australian Government’s significant achievements in improving the economic position of women.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Participation, in writing, on 12 August 2009:

quote.para: What is the average duration of unemployment since the last full-time job for recipients of the:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Newstart Allowance

item.label: (b)
item.para: Parenting Payment

item.label: (c)
item.para: Youth Allowance; and

item.label: (d)
item.para: Disability Support Pension,

quote.para: for each quarter from March 2006 to June 2009.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment Participation has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: Reliable data are not available to answer the honourable member’s question.

A person may become eligible for income support for a range of reasons, including loss or reduction of full-time, part-time or seasonal employment; as a result of a change in their personal circumstances, such as obtaining residency; or through meeting income and asset testing thresholds.

Information on when recipients of Newstart Allowance, Parenting Payment or Youth Allowance were last in employment may be recorded in text on Centrelink’s system where it is relevant to their payment (such as periods relating to paid leave entitlements or a redundancy payment); however, information on when an income support recipient was last in employment is not a reportable data item in the Centrelink system. Therefore, these data cannot be extracted to reliably assess the average duration of unemployment since the last full-time job for such recipients.
Disability Support Pension falls within the responsibilities of the Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Participation, in writing, on 12 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Job Network and related employment services programs such as the Personal Support Programme and Job Placement, Employment and Training, what was the: (a) total number of (i) placements, (ii) commencements, and (iii) employment outcomes; and (b) cost per (i) placement, and (ii) employment outcome; by quarter, from March 2006 to June 2009.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment Participation has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: The following tables shows the total numbers of placements, commencements, and employment outcomes for Job Network, the Personal Support Programme and Job Placement, Employment and Training, by quarter, from March 2006 to June 2009.

Job Placement figures are for Job Network and other Job Placement organisations only. Personal Support Programme and Job Placement, Employment and Training providers were not contracted to deliver services under Job Placement licences, and were not required to record job placements which means that these placements are not recorded here.
The following table provides information on the number of commencements for the three programs.
The following table provides information on the number of outcomes for the three programs.
(1) Job Network
Outcomes are recorded after 13 weeks in employment.
(2) Personal Support Programme
PSP providers were paid Economic Outcome fees where participants were placed into 13 consecutive weeks of employment.
(3) Job Placement, Employment and Training
From 1 July 2007, JPET providers recorded a participant’s employment status at the time of exit from the program. These have been presented as economic outcomes
Costs per placement and employment outcome by quarter, from March 2006 to June 2009.

The Department does not report cost per job placement. This is because not all job seekers who find a job inform their provider or Centrelink. As a result the providers’ contribution to those placements cannot be attributed and any calculation of cost per placement would overstate the actual cost.
Cost per employment outcome under Job Network is sourced from the results of the Department’s Post-Program Monitoring (PPM) survey undertaken three months after job seekers leave assistance.

The cost per employment outcome three months following participation in Job Network Employment Services (Job Placement and Intensive Support) is reported by financial year through the Department’s Annual Report. The results by each quarter from 2006 onwards are presented in the table below. The results for 2008–09 are not yet available.

The Personal Support Programme and Job Placement, Employment and Training program were pre-employment programs providing assistance to people with serious and multiple non-vocational barriers to participation in the labour market. Costs per employment outcome are not available for these non-vocational programs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 12 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Building the Education Revolution—

item.para: How many jobs are estimated to be (a) created, and (b) supported, by the $14.7 billion Revolution in the (i) 2008-09, (ii) 2009-10, (iii) 2010-11, and (iv) 2011-12 financial years.
How many jobs in total are estimated to be (a) created, and (b) supported, by the $14.7 billion Revolution.
What is the cost per job (a) created, and (b) supported, by the $14.7 billion Revolution.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Building the Education Revolution monthly reporting guidelines require states, territories and Block Grant Authorities to provide jobs supported estimated data on the average daily number of on-site workers for the duration of the project.

The Treasury estimates that the Government’s Nation Building – Economic Stimulus Plan will increase the level of GDP by 2¾ per cent in 2009-10 and 1½ per cent in 2010-11, supporting up to 210,000 jobs.
Building the Education Revolution funding has been approved for a total of 24,426 projects in 9,530 schools.

A comprehensive reporting regime has been established through which states, territories and Block Grant Authorities are required to report on actual project commencement, actual project completion, project progress, estimated jobs supported, actual project costs and contracted commitments.

The Building the Education Revolution monthly reporting guidelines require states, territories and Block Grant Authorities to provide jobs supported estimated data on the average daily number of on-site workers for the duration of the project. It is not a requirement for states, territories and Block Grant Authorities to report on the costs of creating or supporting jobs.

quote.para: In respect of the Job Network and related employment services programs such as the Personal Support Programme and Job Placement, Employment and Training: how many job seekers were participating in a mutual obligation activity on 26 June 2009 in (a) total and (b) by mutual obligation activity type.

talker.name: Ms Gillard

item.para: The total number of job seekers participating in a mutual obligation activity as at and including the 26th June 09 was 27 248.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The number of job seekers by each mutual obligation activity type:

This data reflects a job seeker undertaking an activity to meet their first six months mutual obligation requirement, which was a feature of the previous employment services model. It should be noted that outside of this six month requirement, job seekers continue to participate in a range of activities to satisfy their ongoing requirement to actively look for work and participate in employment services in exchange for income support.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Participation, in writing, on 12 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of Job Services Australia: how many job seekers were participating in a Mutual Obligation activity such as Work for the Dole or Green Corps or another Work Experience activity on (a) 1 July 2009, and (b) 1 August 2009 in (i) total, and (ii) by Mutual Obligation activity type.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment Participation has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: Job seekers being serviced under Job Services Australia have an ongoing Mutual Obligation to participate in activities and look for work, in exchange for their income support. Under Job Services Australia, most job seekers who continue in employment services after 12 months will also have a requirement to undertake a Work Experience activity for every twelve months they remain unemployed. Significantly, job seekers can now start a Work Experience activity at any time, if their Job Services Australia provider agrees it is the most appropriate activity to assist a job seeker achieve their employment goals, so they don’t need to wait 12 months to access these services.

During the transition to Job Services Australia, job seekers who were already undertaking an activity, such as Work for the Dole, to meet their six-month Mutual Obligation activity requirement (under Job Network), were supported to continue in those activities. This enabled job seekers to see projects through to completion. Time spent on these activities by job seekers who transitioned immediately into the Work Experience Phase under Job Services Australia was recognised and counted toward their first Work Experience Activity Requirement.

item.para: The number of job seekers participating in Work Experience activities by activity type as at 1 July 2009 was:

(b) As at 1 August 2009

item.label: (ii)
item.para: The number of job seekers participating in Work Experience activities by activity type as at 1 August 2009 was:

entry.para: Voluntary Work in community/non profit sector

Job seekers participating in activities commenced prior to 1 July under the previous employment services to meet their six monthly Mutual Obligation requirement (including Work for the Dole, Voluntary Work, Defence Force Reserve, education and training, part-time work, relocation or any combination of these activities).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Participation, in writing, on 12 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of Green Corps under Job Services Australia –

item.para: As at 12 August 2009, how many participants (a) were undertaking, and (b) are forecast to undertake in the 2009-10 financial year, a Green Corps Work Experience Activity.
As at 12 August 2009, what was the age breakdown of participants in the Green Corps Work Experience Activity.
Is it a demand driven program.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment Participation has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

quote.para: Green Corps under Job Services Australia has been improved and expanded which will limit its comparison to the previous program. Under Job Services Australia:

item.para: Participation in Green Corps activities is available to job seekers of all ages receiving income support payments.

Green Corps activities have been significantly expanded from current arrangements with no limits on places available. Job Services Australia Providers are able to vary the length of activities, with flexible start and end dates, allowing activities to be better targeted to community needs. There is no longer a restriction on projects in urban areas.

quote.para: To 12 August 2009, there were 36 job seekers in Green Corps activities under Job Services Australia. There were also 528 job seekers completing Green Corps activities under the previous Employment Services Contract of 2006-2009. Under Job Services Australia, Green Corps is one of a number of options available to job seekers undertaking Work Experience activities. There is no forecasting for Work Experience activities such as Green Corps as access to all activities is demand driven dependant upon the needs of individual job seekers.
Of the 36 job seekers in Green Corps activities, under Job Services Australia to 12 August 2009, the age breakdown was as follows:

item.para: no job seekers were under 20 years of age
11 job seekers were under 30 years of age
13 job seekers were aged between 30 and 44 years of age, and
12 job seekers were aged 45 years or over.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 12 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Productivity Places Program:

item.para: As at 12 August 2009, how many job seekers, by payment type, (a) were enrolled in (b) had commenced, and (c) had completed a qualification under the program.
As at 12 August 2009, what were the (a) employment outcomes, by payment type, and (b) average employment outcomes, for job seekers who had successfully completed a qualification under the program.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: As at 12 August 2009, there were (a) 132 176 enrolments*, (b) 110 770 commencements**, and (c) 55 383 completions. This data cannot be disaggregated by payment type.
*Under the PPP ‘enrolments’ are participants that have applied, met the programs eligibility criteria and were expected to commence training within six weeks of their approval.

** ‘Commencements’ are recorded when an approved training organisation has commenced delivery of formal training to the eligible participant for an eligible qualification – this milestone triggers the first of two PPP payments – the other being the completion milestone.

As at 12 August 2009, 40 193 job seekers that were referred by an Employment Service Provider (ESP) had completed a PPP qualification and (a) 5 859 of these achieved an ‘employment outcome’. The distribution of ‘employment outcomes’ across payment type is described in Table 1.
No data exists on (b) average employment outcomes.

As the states and territories are delivering job seeker places progressively through 2009, performance data is not yet available. Reports demonstrating progress against output targets are due 31 January 2010.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 13 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Productivity Places Program:
(1) What Funding is the Government providing in the years (a) 2007–2008, (b) 2008–2009, (c) 2009–10, (d) 2010–2011, (e) 2011–2012, and (f) 2012–2013, financial years.
(2) What funding is each State and Territory Government providing in the (a) 2007–2008, (b) 2008–2009, (c) 2009–2010, (d) 2010-–2011, (e) 2011–2012, and (f) 2012–2013, financial years.
(3) What sum of funding has each State and Territory government allocated for this program in their (a) 2008–2009, and (b) 2009–2010, budgets.

item.para: How will the Government measure the actual financial contribution from each State and Territory government.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Government has administered funding appropriated for the following financial years: $27 875 000 in 2007–2008; $336 327 000 in 2008–2009; $487 252 000 in 2009–2010; $523 413 000 in 2010–2011; and $646 003 000 in 2011–2012.

All states except the Government of Victoria are signatories to the National Partnership Agreement on the Productivity Places Program(NP PPP). Under the NP PPP the Australian Government provides 100 per cent of the funding for job seeker places and 50 per cent of funding for existing worker places. States have committed to provide 40 per cent of the funding for existing worker places and put in place arrangements to ensure a collection of a minimum 10 per cent private contribution for existing worker places.
The NP PPP will be in place from 2009 to 30 June 2012 covering financial years 2008–2009 through to 2011–2012. State commitments under the NP PPP for each financial year are below:

Total estimated program expenditure under state delivery of the NP PPP for 2008–2009 and 2009–2010 is outlined below. This includes the Australian Government contribution, state contributions and the minimum 10 percent private contribution.

Under the terms of NP PPP (and Victoria’s agreement) by 31 January each year, state and territory governments will provide the Australian Government with an acquittal of funding over the previous 12 months.

subdebateinfo.title: Compact with Young Australians and Youth Allowance

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 13 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Compact with Young Australians and Youth Allowance (Other)—

item.para: As at 13 August 2009, how many new recipients of the Allowance since 1 July 2009 had a participation requirement under the Compact.
As at 13 August 2009, what was the current average duration of an Allowance recipient.
As at 13 August 2009, what percentage of Allowance recipients exited income support within (a) three months, and (b) twelve months.
As at 13 August 2009, how many Allowance recipients achieved an (a) employment, and (b) education, outcome for each quarter since March 2006.
As at 13 August 2009, what percentage of Allowance recipients achieved an (a) employment, and (b) education, outcome for each quarter since March 2006.
What are the key performance indicators which will be used to measure the elements of the Compact.
What are the estimated (a) employment, and (b) education, outcomes of the Compact.
How will the number of employment outcomes achieved from participation in the Compact be measured.
What is the estimated impact of the Compact on the employment rate of Australians aged 15 to 24.
What monitoring and evaluation of the Compact will be conducted, and on what date will they be made public.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Note: Data as at 14 August 2009 is not readily available. The closest readily available data for each question has been used in the answers below.

item.para: The Compact with Young Australians includes a National Youth Participation Requirement under which young people will be required to complete Year 10 and then undertake full-time education, training, employment, or a combination of these until the age of 17.

To support the Compact, young people aged under 21 seeking Youth Allowance who do not have Year 12 or equivalent (known as Early School Leavers), will be assessed against new participation requirements.

At 14 September 2009, there were approximately 6100 recipients of Youth Allowance (other) who were granted payment on or after 1 July 2009, who did not have Year 12 or equivalent qualifications and were subject to the new participation requirements.
As at 31 July 2009, the average duration on income support for Youth Allowance (other) recipients was 70 weeks.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: As at 31 July 2009, 31 per cent of Youth Allowance (other) recipients exited income support within 3 months of grant.

item.label: (3) (b)
item.para: As at 31 July 2009, 75 per cent of Youth Allowance (other) recipients exited income support within 12 months of grant.
Number of 13 week employment outcomes and number of education outcomes for Youth Allowance (other) recipients for each quarter from March 2006.

Employment outcome payments are made to employment service providers when a job seeker is placed and remains in employment or gains employment for 13 weeks. A second payment is made if the job seeker remains in employment for a further 13 weeks (referred to as a 26 week outcome). Education outcome payments are made when job seekers complete one or two semesters of an eligible education/training course. The table below shows the number of 13 week employment outcomes and the number of education outcomes.

entry.para: Number of 13 week employment outcomes for YA (o) recipients
Number of education outcomes for YA (o) recipients
Total of 13 week employment outcomes and education outcomes for YA(o) recipients

item.para: It is not possible to accurately provide the percentage of Youth Allowance (other) recipients who attained an education or employment outcome for each quarter from March 2006. This is because the outcome data is cumulatively calculated for each quarter, whereas the Youth Allowance (other) population is ‘point in time’ and may have fluctuated over the same quarter reference period.
Under the Compact with Young Australians:

a National Youth Participation Requirement will apply under which young people will be required to complete Year 10 and then undertake full-time education, training, employment, or a combination of these until the age of 17;
state and territory governments have guaranteed young people aged 15 to 24 years access to an education or training entitlement; and
participation requirements will be strengthened for Youth Allowance and children attracting Family Tax Benefit Part A for their parents.

The elements of the Compact are expected to contribute to strengthened participation levels in education and training, resulting in the achievement of the 90 per cent national Year 12 or equivalent attainment rate target by 2015 (which was brought forward from 2020 under the Compact).

(7) (a) There are no estimated employment outcomes under the Compact with Young Australians. The intention of the education and training entitlement is to enable young people—especially those vulnerable to the tightened labour market effect of the global recession—to be better prepared and qualified for a transition into the workforce particularly as the economy recovers.

(b) The Government estimates that the education and training entitlement under the Compact with Young Australians will result in up to 135,000 young people being encouraged to return to education and training or undertake further education and training to improve their skills and current qualifications.

The Government expects that most early school leavers who take up a Compact place will seek VET training. Early modelling work undertaken by the Department suggested that up to 14,000 young people may take up a school place as a result of the Compact.
(8) See response to 7(a).
(9) See response to 7(a).

(10) The States and Territories are responsible for the implementation of the Compact with Young Australians. Clause 58 (b) of the National Partnership Agreement on Youth Attainment and Transitions states that within the COAG framework, the Commonwealth, the States and Territories will develop an information exchange protocol between Centrelink and education and training authorities to assist with monitoring and implementation of the Compact’s National Youth Participation Requirement.

Clause 58 (i) states that the development of a formative evaluation of initiatives covered by the Agreement will be undertaken to support further policy development and continuous improvement. This evaluation has not yet been developed but will be done so in collaboration with the States and Territories, once their respective Implementation Plans and reform areas have been agreed by the end of November 2009.

Clause 40 states the education and training entitlement will be reviewed in April 2011 by COAG Senior Officials who will report to COAG on the effectiveness of the education and training entitlement and make recommendations to COAG on whether the entitlement should be extended past 31 December 2011. The specific parameters surrounding the effectiveness of the entitlement have not yet been determined by COAG Senior Officials, but the economic conditions at the time will be considered.
The National Partnership Agreement does not specify whether the reviews conducted will be made publicly available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 13 August:

quote.para: In respect of the upgrading of skills component for existing workers under the Productivity Places Program:

item.para: As of 13 August 2009 and by State and Territory: How many existing workers had (a) enrolled in, (b) commenced, and (c) graduated from the program; and in what qualifications and at what levels were these places taken up.
As of 13 August 2009 and by State and Territory, how many existing workers had reported an improved employment status after completing their upgrading of skills training under the program.
As of 13 August 2009 and by State and Territory, what percentage of existing workers had reported an improved employment status after completing their upgrading of skills training under the program.
As of 13 August 2009 and by State and Territory, what has the Governments monetary contribution for upgrading the skills of existing workers under the program.
As of 13 August 2009 and by State and Territory, what has been the monetary contribution of each State and territory for upgrading the skills of existing workers under the program.

As of 13 August 2009 and by State and Territory, what has been the employer or individual monetary contribution of each State and territory for upgrading the skills of existing workers under the program.
What evaluation and monitoring of this program are being undertaken, and on what dates will the results be made public.
What are the key Performance Indicators for the upgrading of skills component of this program.
As of 13 August 2009, and for each State and territory, what are the values for each of the measured performance indicators.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Most states and territories (states) are in early stages of implementation of the existing worker element of the Productivity Places Program (PPP). The number of commencements is expected to rise from September to December with over 57,000 commencements anticipated to occur by 31 December 2009. Reports from seven states indicate that as of 1 August 2009 arrangements have been put in place for the delivery of over 30,000 places to existing workers.

Preliminary data from five states indicates that over 12,000 existing workers have commenced training under the Productivity Places Program to 1 August 2009. This includes an estimated 1,250 commencements for existing workers through a series of national enterprise trials and 11,475 commencements for existing workers under state delivery arrangements. This figure is an underestimate as it excludes data for 2009 for Queensland and Western Australia as data on commencements have yet to be provided by these two states. This figure excludes existing workers at risk of retrenchment who have received training under the structural adjustment component of the job seeker element of the PPP (approximately 7,000 workers). Data on completions are not yet available for all states.

The data also exclude additional training effort in Victoria during 2009. Victoria is not a signatory to the National Partnership Agreement on the PPP (NP PPP). Victoria has negotiated a separate arrangement with the Commonwealth Government. This arrangement will see PPP funding incorporated into Victoria’s existing arrangements to support its reform process Securing Jobs for Your Future – Skills for Victoria. As part of this agreement the two governments agreed that a separate Productivity Places Program (PPP) will not operate in Victoria and ongoing PPP funding will instead be incorporated into existing skills funding arrangements on certain conditions, including that Victoria report on overall growth in delivery and higher level qualifications to both job seekers and existing workers.

The table below shows preliminary data by qualification level on how many existing workers have commenced training through the PPP under state delivery arrangements. Data on existing workers participating in the national enterprise trials have not been collected at state level as projects were brokered by Industry Skills Councils at the national level and not individual jurisdictions. Data on additional training effort in during 2009 in Victoria, Queensland Western Australia are not included. A breakdown of unpublished data by state and territory should be obtained directly from each state government.
Table 1 Existing Worker Qualification Commencements under State Delivery Arrangements – Preliminary Data on Delivery to 1 August 2009
A breakdown of commencements by qualification has not yet been provided by all states.

and (3) The existing worker element of the program is in early stages of implementation. Qualitative data on progress has been collected but the qualitative information that would enable this question to be answered has not yet been collected. It is anticipated that qualitative information will be collected as part of the mid-term review of the funding and operational arrangements of the National Partnership Agreement which is due to occur no later than 30 June 2010.

Over $74 million has been notionally provided by the Australian Government as of 13 August 2009 to support training for existing workers under the Productivity Places Program – $17 million through MoUs with all states, $3 million through national enterprise trials and $54 million as a notional payment under the National Partnership Agreement with seven states. In addition a further $15 million has been provided to the Victorian Government to support additional training for existing workers through existing skilling arrangements taking the total Australian Government contribution to date to over $89 million.

The table below shows, by state, the Australian Government’s notional contribution as of 18 August 2009 for state delivery of the PPP to existing workers under MoU arrangements and the National Partnership Agreement on the PPP. It also shows the funding contribution that the Australian Government has committed to provide each state for the full 2009 calendar year. These payments are notional only as under the new federal financial framework there are centralised payment arrangements and states do not receive a separate payment for existing workers and job seekers. This notional split of the payments does not reflect how the funds are transferred between governments.

A state by state breakdown of funding provided under national enterprise trials is not available as funding was directed to projects brokered by Industry Skills Councils rather than into individual jurisdictions.
Table 2 PPP – Notional Payments to States for delivery to Existing Workers, 2008 to 2009

Under the terms and conditions of the National Partnership Agreement on the PPP there is a calendar year target for the delivery of training to existing workers. States are required to contribute funding to support this commitment. Data on financial contributions by states are acquitted on an annual basis with the first report due on 31 January 2010. The table below shows the funding contribution that each state has committed to provide under MoU arrangements and under the National Partnership for the 2009 calendar year. Data on actual state funding contributions to 13 August 2009 should be sought directly from state governments.
Table 3 State Funding Commitments for Delivery to Existing Workers

Under the terms and conditions of the National Partnership Agreement on the PPP there is a calendar year target for the delivery of training to existing workers. In addition to contributing funding to support this commitment states are required to put in place arrangements to collect in aggregate a minimum 10 per cent private contribution. Financial data will be acquitted on an annual basis with the first report due on 31 January 2010. The table below shows the minimum 10 per cent private contribution equivalent to the outputs that each state has committed to provide for the 2009 calendar year. Data on the private contribution to 13 August 2009 are not available.
Table 4 Notional Private Funding Contribution for Delivery to Existing Workers
Under the National Partnership Agreement on the PPP states are required to provide:

item.label: (a)
item.para: monthly progress reports on the implementation of the PPP;

item.label: (b)
item.para: six monthly reports on progress against PPP output targets and an analysis of barriers and achievements in meeting the targets; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: annual financial reports to acquit funding.
Through the NP PPP all governments aim to increase the number of people with qualifications and the number of people with higher level qualifications. States are required to ensure that:
Additional training is made available for job seekers and existing workers.
Additional training is targeted in accordance with the agreed national qualification profile level.
Additional training is targeted at industries, occupations and qualifications in skills shortage.
The conditions of agreement, including the following are met:
training funded under the Agreement is in addition in existing effort;
enterprises and industry representatives are engaged in the program to identify skills needs and facilitate the delivery of training;
there is a role for national Industry Skills Councils in the brokerage of training;
there is a role for Employment Service Providers in the brokerage of training;
a contestable environment for the delivery of training in which public and private providers can compete;
40 per cent of funding for existing worker places is provided by state governments; and
a minimum 10 per cent enterprise/individual contribution for existing worker places is collected in aggregate over the life of the Agreement.
State progress will be measured through data and reporting arrangements as set out in (7).

(9) Under the terms and conditions of the NP PPP states are required to meet a calendar year target for the delivery of training to existing workers and contribute funding to support this commitment. Data to enable an assessment of the performance of states against 2009 targets will not be available until 31 January 2010. Preliminary data indicates that as result of the present economic climate there is a high demand for training at lower qualification levels and the demand for job seeker places exceeds supply.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Housing and the Minister for the Status of Women, in writing, on 13 August 2009.

quote.para: In respect of the National Rental Affordability Scheme (NRAS):

item.para: Does her department require proponents to submit evidence that their proposals are compliant with local planning and building codes; if not, why not.
Has her department issued any incentives to proponents that have failed to comply with the requirements of local planning and building codes; if so, why, and in which locations.

Will she indicate what steps are taken by her department to ensure that proposals seeking to take up NRAS incentives have complied with the requirements of all local planning and building codes; if not, why not.

Does her department defer consideration of applications for NRAS incentives until proponents have received the relevant development approvals from State or local government authorities; if not, why not.

Has her department made any representations to local government authorities regarding any application for NRAS incentives; if so, would it support variations to planning requirements (such as building height) to enable an affordable housing proposal to proceed; if so, why.

talker.name: Plibersek, Tanya, MP
talker.role: Minister for Housing and Minister for the Status of Women
talker.name: Ms Plibersek

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The National Rental Affordability Scheme Regulations 2008, Regulation 16, requires that each approved rental dwelling, and the management of it, complies at all times with the landlord, tenancy, building and health and safety laws of the State or Territory and local government area in which the dwelling is located.

As part of the application process, while applicants are not required to provide evidence that their proposals are compliant with local planning or building codes, or obtained planning approval, they are required to sign a declaration which states that they will be fully compliant. This allows for applicants to forward plan and to include projects that will deliver dwellings over the four years of NRAS 2008-2012. A reserved allocation of incentives may be offered without this evidence, however, no incentive will be provided, either as a payment or refundable tax offset, until the dwelling meets all requirements of the Scheme, including Regulation 16 above, and is available for rent.

As mentioned above, dwellings must comply with the landlord, tenancy, building and health and safety laws of the relevant state or territory. An incentive would not be provided where the Department was aware that this requirement had not been met.

All applicants are required to sign a declaration indicating that they will be fully compliant with the National Mandatory Requirements for NRAS, one of which is that “dwellings will comply with State, Territory and Local Government planning and building codes and requirements”. In addition, applicants are also required to indicate the status of their projects (eg. land acquired, design stage, planning approval received, construction commenced/completed). While evidence to support these claims is not required as part of the application process, where there is some doubt during the assessment process about the claims being made, this information has been requested.

For those applications which have been approved, incentives are issued in arrears following an annual reporting period. Approved participants must indicate that they have complied with local regulations and provide a copy of the certificate of occupancy or equivalent for each dwelling.

Reserved allocations may be offered to applicants prior to obtaining planning approval. Gaining approval under the Scheme may be a critical part of proceeding with the project and applicants may need or wish to secure this prior to applying for planning approval. Approval under the Scheme may be a way for applicants to secure finance to commence the development. Relevant laws must be complied with and no incentive will be provided, either through payment or refundable tax offset, until the dwelling has met the requirements of the Scheme.

The Department has not made any representations for, and does not advocate on behalf of, applicants seeking planning approval or variations to building requirements. Planning approval would be made at the discretion of the relevant local council in line with their usual practices and with reference to their requirements and town plans.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 17 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of his department’s Local Government National Report for 2006-2007, tabled in the House of Representatives on 11 August 2009—

item.para: Is he aware that this report indicates that as many as 169 of Australia’s local councils may be financially unviable; if not, why not.
Is he aware that the number of financially unviable councils has increased by six since the release of the Local Government National Report for 2005-2006; if not, why not.

Has he contacted the New South Wales, Victorian, West Australian, South Australian and Tasmanian governments to discuss their management of local government within their jurisdictions; if not, why not.
What structural reforms to local government has the Government enacted to ensure the long term financial viability of local government as a level of government in Australia.

Is the Government intending to make any long term reforms to the financial relationships between all levels of government beyond the current Community Infrastructure component of the economic security strategy; if not, why not.

talker.name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
talker.name: Mr Albanese

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: to (5) Under the Australian Constitution states and territories have primary responsibility for local government and their reform. The Australian Government is assisting in this process with the $25 million Local Government Reform Fund announced by the Prime Minister, the Hon Kevin Rudd MP, at the June 2009 meeting of the Australian Council of Local Government. We are also establishing the Centre for Excellence for Local Government to enhance professionalism and showcase innovation and best practice in the local government sector.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 17 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of a submission by Caritas College at Port Augusta, South Australia, for funding under the Building the Education Revolution program to construct a science centre: (a) why was the College’s application unsuccessful; and (b) did her department recommend funding be refused.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: As part of the application process, each state and territory education authority was required to conduct a competitive process seeking applications from secondary schools within their sector.

Funding for Science and Language Centres (SLC) under the Building the Education Revolution program was allocated on the basis of demonstrated disadvantage, demonstrated need for the specified building and the capacity to complete construction within the 2009–10 financial year. A National Assessment Panel of experts assessed the applications submitted to my Department on the strength of the information provided in response to each of the criteria.
The National Assessment Panel provided me with a list of the projects deemed suitable in accordance with the assessment criteria and a recommendation for their funding for my consideration.

The National Assessment Panel found that Caritas College’s case for disadvantage was not clearly demonstrated and rated a lower score than other applications from schools across Australia. Subsequently, the College was not recommended as suitable for SLC funding.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 20 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of remarks attributed to the Premier of Western Australia (WA) during WA Local Government Week from 6 to 8 August 2009, where it was said that the Australian Government was no longer prepared to fund 139 Local Government authorities in WA, and that unless there was a reduction, it would cut financial assistance: does he or the Australian Government intend to change the law or guidelines relating to the funding of Local Government, such as Financial Assistance Grants or Roads to Recovery, with the intention of causing Local Government authorities in WA to amalgamate.

talker.name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
talker.name: Mr Albanese

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Neither I nor the Australian Government intend to change any such laws or guidelines. The Government has no powers to direct the Western Australian Government on the structure of local government, which operates under Western Australian legislation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 20 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of Stewart House and Royal Far West Schools on Sydney’s Northern Beaches being ineligible for funding under the Government’s education revolution program because their pupils are not categorised as permanently enrolled students –

item.para: When and how will she intervene to ensure that these two schools receive funding.
Is it the position of the Australian Government that the NSW Government should provide more funding to these schools.

Did she write a letter to the NSW Minister for Education, requesting that the NSW Government provide additional funding for these two schools; if so, has she received a response; if so, what was the response.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: All funding for the Building the Education Revolution (BER) program has now been allocated and finalised. Under the BER Guidelines, funding is based on a school’s full-time student enrolment (FTE). As Stewart House and Royal Far West Schools do not have a permanently enrolled student population, they are not eligible for BER funding. The FTE associated with the students that attend either Stewart House School or Royal Far West School has been used to calculate the notional BER funding of their home school.
This is a matter for the NSW Government.

In recognition of the valuable work carried out by these schools, on 12 August 2009 Minister Gillard wrote to the Hon Verity Firth MP, New South Wales Minister for Education and Training in support of Stewart House and Royal Far West Schools. It is understood that the NSW Government is currently modelling funding options for specialist schools, such as Stewart House School, that do not meet the funding eligibility requirements of the BER.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 20 August 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Productivity Places Program by level of qualifications, what is the average duration of training for (a) job seekers, and (b) existing workers, who complete a qualification under the program.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The average duration of training for (a) job seekers who have completed a qualification under the program is 69 days for Certificate II level, 105 days for Certificate III level, 113 days for Certificate IV level and 288 days for Diploma level (see table 1).

Data is not yet available at this level of detail for existing workers. Full reporting and reconciliation of activity by states and territories occurs annually in accordance with the National Partnership Agreement provisions. The first annual reconciliation is due in January 2010.
Table 1: Average duration of training by qualification level for job seekers who have completed PPP training delivered by the Australian Government

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 7 September 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Centrelink office at Southport, Queensland

item.para: What funds were appropriated to this office for the 2008-09 financial year.
What funds have been appropriated to this office (a) for the 2009-10 financial year, and (b) over the forward estimates years.

How many staff were employed at this office as at 7 September 2009, how many of these were employed on a full-time basis, and what is the total budgeted funding for salaries and wages of staff in the 2009-10 financial year.
How many (a) clients were seen, and (b) counter enquiries were made, at this office between 1 July 2008 and 30 June 2009.

talker.name: Bowen, Chris, MP
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services, Superannuation and Corporate Law and Minister for Human Services
talker.name: Mr Bowen

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Funding for Centrelink Customer Service Centres in the northern Gold Coast region (Biggera Waters, Nerang and Southport) is not appropriated to individual offices. As customers in this region use one or more of these offices regularly, resource management in the region is managed centrally to ensure maximum flexibility to meet fluctuating demand. Funds were not appropriated to the Southport office for the 2008-09 financial year. Customers in the northern Gold Coast region attend the office that is most convenient to their work, study, employer provider and/or home.

As noted in question 1, funding for 2009-10 and the Southport office is not fixed. Funding for future financial years, including 2009-10 and over forward estimate years will be subject to customer demand and changes to service delivery. Funding will continue to be allocated to the Northern Gold Coast cluster of offices to ensure that the Biggera Waters, Southport and Nerang offices are able to respond effectively to changing customer demographics and demands.

On 7 September 2009, 37 employees worked at Southport Customer Service Centre, of whom 29 were employed on a full time basis. The total budgeted funding for salaries and wages for staff for the 2009-10 financial year cannot be provided specific to Southport, as noted above.

Centrelink is unable to answer this question completely as it does not currently capture the total number of customers who attend a Customer Service Centre. Centrelink is able to advise that there were approximately 382,000 instances where customers reported income or were recorded at a reception point in Southport in 2008-09. Of these, 87,345 were instances of customers reporting income at Southport and 294,065 were recorded reception contacts. Data on reception contacts does not include situations where a customer’s record was not accessed and may not include situations where the customer was seen by a Customer Liaison Officer prior to reaching a reception point.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 7 September 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Medicare Family Assistance Office at Pacific Fair, Broadbeach, Queensland—

item.para: What funds were appropriated to this office for the 2008-09 financial year.
What funds have been appropriated to this office (a) for the 2009-10 financial year, and (b) over the forward estimates years.

How many staff were employed at this office as at 7 September 2009, how many of these were employed on a full-time basis, and what is the total budgeted funding for salaries and wages of staff in the 2009-10 financial year.
How many (a) clients were seen, and (b) counter enquiries were made, at this office between 1 July 2008 and 30 June 2009.

talker.name: Bowen, Chris, MP
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services, Superannuation and Corporate Law and Minister for Human Services
talker.name: Mr Bowen

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Medicare Family Assistance Office at Pacific Fair, Broadbeach, Queensland was established on 12 February 1998. The funding for this office is included at an aggregate level across Medicare Australia’s programs and is not appropriated separately.
A budget was allocated to each Medicare Australia office in the 2008–09 financial year. The estimated expenditure for Pacific Fair was $1,137,760.
The expected expenditure for the Pacific Fair Medicare office in 2009–10 is $1,135,624.

Medicare Australia is not anticipating any significant changes to the operations of the Pacific Fair Medicare office over the forward estimates period. Medicare Australia does not therefore expect any significant change to the cost profile for this office.

As at 7 September 2009, 11 fulltime and one part time staff were employed at the Pacific Fair Medicare office (a further three fulltime staff and one part time staff were on maternity leave). An amount of $816,190 is budgeted for salaries and wages of staff in 2009–10.
Between 1 July, 2008 and 30 June 2009, 176,665 customers received services in this office. Of this 29,428 made enquiries, the remainder received financial transaction services.
