talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 7 September 2009:

item.para: Is he aware that Ahmad Vahidi, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s nomination to serve as Iran’s Defence Minister, is a suspected international terrorist sought by Interpol in connection with several bombings in the early 1990s.
Has Interpol issued a warrant for his arrest; if so, does it specifically relate to his connection with the 1994 attack on a Jewish community centre in Argentina which killed 85 people.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Mr Vahidi is wanted for prosecution by Argentinean authorities for alleged involvement in the bombing of the Argentine Israeli Mutual Association (AMIA) centre in Buenos Aires in 1994. Mr Vahidi is the subject of an Interpol Red Notice. An Interpol Red Notice is a non-binding notification of the issue of a valid arrest warrant in an Interpol member country, with a view to enforcement facilitation. The Red Notice against Mr Vahidi was published in November 2007 at the request of Argentina.

Interpol has issued a Red Notice, which is an international alert for a wanted person, not an international arrest warrant (although some countries will arrest a person who is the subject of an Interpol Red Notice, without requiring further extradition documents from the requesting country). In November 2006, the Argentine court investigating the 1994 bombing of the Argentine Israeli Mutual Association (AMIA) centre in Buenos Aires issued an arrest warrant for Mr Vahidi in relation to his alleged involvement in the bombing.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, in writing, on 7 September 2009:

quote.para: In respect of Britain’s High Court decision to allow a case, brought by veterans seeking compensation for adverse health effects from nuclear tests performed in the 1950s in the Pacific, to proceed against Britain’s Ministry of Defence

item.para: Will the Australian Government consider allowing a case to be brought against it by Australian veterans who were exposed to nuclear radiation at Maralinga, Emu Field and on Malden Island and Christmas Island in the 1950s; if so, when; if not, why not.

Alternatively, will the Australian Government consider seeking, on behalf of Australian veterans who were exposed to nuclear radiation at Maralinga, Emu Field and on Malden Island and Christmas Island in the 1950s, compensation from the British Government; if so, when; if not, why not.

Alternatively, will the Australian Government, on its own initiative, consider providing compensation to surviving Australian veterans who were exposed to nuclear radiation at Maralinga, Emu Field and on Malden Island and Christmas Island in the 1950s; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Griffin, Alan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Veterans’ Affairs
talker.name: Mr Griffin

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: It is up to an individual or a class of individuals to bring forward a common law class action in the Courts in respect of their participation in the British Nuclear Tests Program in Australia. I am not aware of any notice that has been served on the Federal Government in relation to this. Decisions on allowing cases to be brought rest with the Courts rather than with the Government. The Government will respond if and when such a notice is served.
My Department is considering the implications of the British High Court’s decision in consultation with other relevant agencies.

Compensation is available to Australian Defence Force (ADF) members and Commonwealth employees who participated in the British Nuclear Test Program in Australia, or their widow(er)s, through the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRCA). Civilians (including pastoralists and Indigenous Australians) have access to compensation through the SRCA-like scheme administered by the Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations.

As one of the Australian Government’s election commitments, I am currently revisiting the unimplemented recommendations of the Clarke Review into Veterans’ Entitlements including the Review’s recommendation relating to participants in the nuclear test program.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 9 September 2009:

quote.para: Is the Government aware of claims by the Central Tibetan Administration that a large number of Tibetans have been imprisoned for acts of peaceful political expression; if so,

item.para: Is the Government aware of the specific case of: (a) Sangye Lhamo, age 26, and Pema Yangtso, both nieces of Tibetan-Australian Geshe Sonam Dargye, arrested for peaceful protests in Kardze Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture; (b) Wangdu, age 41, former project officer with the AusAid-funded HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) Prevention in Lhasa Project, sentenced to life imprisonment; (c) Dhondup Wangchen, age 34, Tibetan filmmaker arrested in Tsoshar, Eastern Tibet in March 2008 and awaiting trial in Xining, Qinghai province; (d) Runggye Adak, age 54, Tibetan nomad arrested in Lithang, Eastern Tibet in 2007 and sentenced to eight years after calling publicly for the return of the Dalai Lama; (e) Tenzin Delek Rinpoche, age 58, religious leader and community builder, arrested in Kandze, Eastern Tibet in 2002 and sentenced to death, commuted to life imprisonment in 2005; (f) Gonpo Tserang, age 32, tourist guide, arrested in Dechen, Yunnan province in 2008 and sentenced to three years for text messaging; (g) Bangri Rinpoche, age 42, arrested in Lhasa in 1999 and sentenced to 19 years for passing information outside of Tibet; (h) Lobsang Tenzin, age 42, arrested in Lhasa in 1989 for peaceful protest, sentenced to life imprisonment; (i) Norzin Wangmo, age 30, journalist and cadre, arrested in Ngaba Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture in 2008 and sentenced to five years for passing information by phone and email outside of Tibet; (j) Paljor Norrbu, age 81, printer, arrested in 2008 and sentenced to seven years for printing materials deemed to be subversive; and (k) Gedun Choekyi Nyima, age 6, (the Panchen Lama identified by the Dalai Lama), detained in 1995.

Has the Government obtained any information about the location, welfare, and where applicable, charges or sentences facing the above Tibetans; if so, can he provide the details and say whether they have been independently verified; if not, what steps will the Government take to obtain such information.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: to (k) Yes.

The Australian Government raised the cases of (a) Sangye Lamo, (b) Wangdu, (c) Dhondup Wangchen, (d) Rungye Adak, (i) Norzin Wangmo, (j) Paljor Norrbu and (k) Gedun Choekyi in the context of the 2009 Australia-China Human Rights Dialogue. Following the Dialogue, the Australian Government raised the case of (a) Pema Yangtso.
Based on information provided by the Chinese authorities, we can advise that:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Sangye Lhamo was accused of “splittist” activities in Ganzi County, Sichuan Province, and placed in an education-through-labour program for two years from 27 June 2008.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Wang du (Wang Due) was sentenced in October 2008 by the Lhasa Intermediate People’s Court to life imprisonment and deprivation of political rights for life for espionage.

item.label: (d)
item.para: Rungyye Adak was sentenced in October 2007 by the Ganzi Prefecture Intermediate People’s Court, Sichuan Province, to eight years imprisonment with deprival of political rights for four years for inciting “splitting of the state”.

item.label: (i)
item.para: Based on the information which we provided, the Chinese authorities were unable to trace an individual by the name of Norzin Wangmo.

item.label: (k)
item.para: Gedun Choekyi Nyima was living a normal life and was doing well academically, but his family had asked that they be left alone.

No information has been received so far on the cases of (a) Pema Yangtso, (c) Dhondup Wangchen and (j) Paljor Norrbu. On 7 September 2009, we instructed the Australian Embassy in Beijing to follow up these cases with the relevant Chinese authorities.

The Australian Government raised the case of (e) Tenzin Delek Rinpoche in the context of the 2007 Australia-China Human Rights Dialogue. The Chinese side advised that he was serving a life sentence in Chuandong Prison, Sichuan Province, after his death sentence was commuted to life in prison on 26 January 2005.
The Australian Government will continue to take appropriate opportunities to raise with Chinese authorities individual cases of human rights concern in China.
The Australian Government is not able to independently verify the information provided by the Chinese Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 9 September 2009:

item.para: Further to question No. 971 (Notice Paper, 7 September 2009, page 70), is he able to confirm that Ahmad Vahidi, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s nomination to serve as Iran’s Defence Minister, is a suspected international terrorist on Interpol’s Red Notice in connection with several bombings in the early 1990s.

Is he able to say whether Argentina issued a warrant for his arrest; if so, can he say if it specifically relates to his connection with the 1994 attack on a Jewish Community centre in Argentina which killed 85 people.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Mr Ahmad Vahidi is the subject of an Interpol Red Notice. An Interpol Red Notice is a non-binding notification of the issue of a valid arrest warrant in an Interpol member country, with a view to enforcement facilitation. The Red Notice against Mr Vahidi was published in November 2007 at the request of Argentina, where he is wanted for prosecution for his alleged involvement in the bombing of the Argentine Israeli Mutual Association (AMIA) centre in Buenos Aires in 1994.

In November 2006, the Argentine court investigating the 1994 bombing of the Argentine Israeli Mutual Association (AMIA) centre in Buenos Aires issued an arrest warrant for Mr Vahidi in relation to his alleged involvement in the bombing.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 10 September 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the case of Australian-passport holder and United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) spokesperson in Sri Lanka, Mr James Elder—

item.para: Can he confirm on behalf of the Australian Government that Mr Elder has represented UNICEF well in being a ‘voice for the voiceless’, and that his comments promoting the interests of children in refugee camps were made (a) without fear or favour, and (b) entirely within his job description.

Can he further confirm on behalf of the Australian Government that Mr Elder is not a ‘promoter of propaganda’ or ‘a terrorist’, as implied by comments in media reports based on the Sri Lankan Government’s withdrawal of his visa.

If the Australian Government confirms parts (1) and (2), is it making representations at the highest level to the Sri Lankan Government to express this view, so that future Australian passport holders who may want to undertake aid work through the appropriate international agencies can do so in full confidence that they have the active support of the Australian Government.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: & (2) As I (Mr Smith) told the House on 14 September, I have looked at Mr Elder’s reported remarks and they do not cause me any difficulty. Mr Elder has been making the point, as has the Australian Government, that we need to see unimpeded access by international agencies to the camps for internally displaced people. I commend the work of UNICEF, with which Australia works closely and which does vitally important work in Sri Lanka and around the world.

The matter of Mr Elder’s visa is one for the Sri Lankan Government, Mr Elder and the United Nations to resolve. Mr Elder and UN officials have indicated to Australian officials that representations by Australia to the Sri Lankan Government regarding the visa were not required. In numerous representations to Sri Lankan government ministers and officials, Australia has made clear its view that international organisations should be given the access and information they need to help meet the needs of displaced persons. Australia has also made clear its strong support for freedom of expression in Sri Lanka, and its view that freedom of expression will be important in encouraging reconciliation between communities and providing non-violent avenues for Sri Lankans to express their grievances.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 14 September 2009:

quote.para: Can he confirm the Government’s position on Burma developing nuclear capabilities; if so, does it include actions to stop Burma’s nuclear program.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The Australian Government is concerned that Burma comply with its obligations as a party to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), including that any nuclear facilities, equipment and materials are made available for application of safeguards by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).

The Government is aware that Russia and Burma concluded an agreement on the construction of a nuclear research reactor in Burma in 2007. Construction of the reactor has not yet begun. Cooperation on nuclear activities must be consistent with both countries’ obligations under the NPT and meet IAEA requirements.

The Government is aware of unconfirmed reports that Burma may be developing a clandestine nuclear program with assistance from the Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea (DPRK). The Government will continue to monitor developments in Burma and urge the Government of Burma to comply with its obligations under the NPT and under United Nations Security Council Resolutions 1874 and 1718 relating to the DPRK.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 15 September 2009:

quote.para: What was the full cost to the Government of hosting the Rwandan delegation to Australia in June 2009.

talker.name: Rudd, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr Rudd

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: As at 17 September 2009, the cost of the visit by the Honourable Mrs Rosemary Museminali, Minister for Foreign Affairs and Regional Cooperation in the Government of Rwanda, was $29,454.89.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 15 September 2009:

item.para: How many countries have formally pledged their support for Australia’s bid for a temporary seat on the United Nations Security Council, and when were such pledges made.
What have been the costs, including any commitments for future expenditure, associated with gaining these pledges of support from each country.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Offers of support are generally made on a confidential basis. Disclosure of numbers and dates can put this confidentiality at risk and also provide valuable information that would assist Australia’s competitors. Australia’s bid was publicly endorsed by the Pacific Islands Forum in 2008 and 2009.
Funding associated with Australia’s campaign is set out in the relevant budget papers. Allocations by financial year are: 2008-09 $1.9m; 2009-10: $5.4m; 2010-11: $5.7m.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 15 September 2009:

quote.para: Since he was sworn in, how many Heads of Missions in Australia has he met with, and how many times has each Head of Mission in Australia met with him.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: I have met with most Heads of Mission. To provide more detailed information would entail a significant diversion of resources which I do not consider justified. No comprehensive records are kept of all the times I have met with each Head of Mission.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 15 September 2009:

item.para: What is the Government’s objective in joining the Asia-Europe Meeting.
Was the bid for a temporary United Nations Security Council seat a consideration when deciding to join the Asia-Europe Meeting.
What were the costs of joining the Asia-Europe Meeting, including those associated with travel.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Membership of the Asia-Europe Meeting will advance Australia’s national interests. It will strengthen Australia’s ties with two regions of great importance to Australia’s prosperity and security. It will allow Australia to make a contribution to efforts to promote dialogue and cooperation between Europe and Asia.

The Asia-Europe Meeting comprises 43 countries from Asia and Europe, along with the European Commission and ASEAN. It fosters cooperation on a range of issues of importance to Australia. For example, the dialogue encourages effective regional and global approaches to international problems such as the global economic crisis, climate change and realisation of the Millennium Development Goals.

Australia attempted to join ASEM in 1996 and 1998, without success. However, at the last meeting of ASEM Foreign Ministers in Hanoi (25-26 May, 2009), ASEM welcomed our membership and participation at the Brussels Summit (4-5 October, 2010). This was a collective recognition by the countries of ASEM of the strong contribution Australia can and will make to the ASEM process.

Australia’s participation in the Asia Europe Meeting process demonstrates the Government’s commitment to working regionally and multilaterally to address economic, political and security challenges. It demonstrates the Government’s commitment to the strongest possible relations with our Asian neighbours and it complements our engagement in other regional groupings such as the East Asia Summit and APEC. It reflects also our now strong and modern partnership with Europe.
No.

During the course of pre-planned travel, I (Mr Smith) raised Australia’s interest in joining ASEM with relevant counterparts. A Deputy Secretary from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade undertook two overseas trips to promote Australia’s interest in joining ASEM. The first was to Cambodia and India from 4-8 January, 2009. The total cost for this travel was $11, 909.76. The second was to Singapore, Vietnam and Jakarta from 11-16 May. The total cost for this travel was $8,657.87. My department managed the daily running of the campaign from within existing resources.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 15 September 2009:

item.para: Which countries have expressed strong support for the idea of a European Union-style community in the Asia Pacific, and (a) how, and (b) on what dates, was this support expressed.
As at 14 September 2009, what was the cost of promoting the idea of an Asia Pacific Community, including that associated with travel.

talker.name: Smith, Stephen, MP
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs
talker.name: Mr Stephen Smith

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: A number of countries have expressed strong support for the Prime Minister’s Asia Pacific community initiative. Consistent with the practice of successive Governments, it would be inappropriate to provide details of confidential discussions with other governments.
The Asia Pacific community will not be modelled on the European Union.

The Government spent around $409,000 on advancing the Asia Pacific community initiative to 14 September 2009. This figure includes travel costs and Mr Richard Woolcott’s consultancy fees but does not include indirect costs, such as time spent on the initiative by departmental officers, as they are difficult to quantify.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, in writing, on 15 September 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Australia-China free trade agreement: (a) on what date(s) was the last round of negotiations held, and what progress was made, and (b) for what date is the next round of negotiations scheduled.

talker.name: Crean, Simon, MP
talker.role: Minister for Trade
talker.name: Mr Crean

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The last round of negotiations for an Australia-China free trade agreement (FTA) was held on 1 to 5 December 2008. The round continued discussion of respective sensitivities to tariff liberalisation and requests for services and investment liberalisation. Progress was made on the text of many of the FTA’s chapters.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Ministerial and officials-level discussions have been continuing, but the next formal round of negotiations has not been scheduled, as yet. Most recently, informal discussions led by chief negotiators were held in Beijing on 7-8 September 2009.

subdebateinfo.title: Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government: Projects

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 15 September 2009:

item.para: As at 15 September 2009, how many projects have been initiated since the Council of Australian Governments Agreement of 5 February 2009?
What sum of money has been spent on these projects?
What is the nature of these projects?
What are the timeframes for these projects?

talker.name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
talker.name: Mr Albanese

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government maintains several program websites on behalf of the Government that display all approved projects. Given the significant number of projects in the portfolio it is not practical to provide a single list of projects.

subdebateinfo.title: Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government: Projects

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 15 September 2009:

item.para: As at 15 September 2009, how many projects have been completed since the Council of Australian Governments Agreement of 5 February 2009.
What sum of money was spent on these projects.
What was the nature of these projects.

talker.name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
talker.name: Mr Albanese

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Refer to answer 1024.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on the 15 September 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Building the Education Revolution, had (a) 20 per cent of school infrastructure projects commenced by 1 June 2009, (b) 40 per cent of school infrastructure projects commenced by 1 August 2009; (c) all science and language centre infrastructure projects commenced by 15 September 2009; (d) 60 percent of national school pride projects commenced by 1 May 2009; and (e) 40 percent of national school pride infrastructure projects commenced by 1 July 2009; if not, why not, and when did they or will they commence.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government has referred your question to me as the Minister responsible for the Building the Education Revolution.
Education Authorities are required to report monthly at the end of each month on project progress across all elements of the BER. Activity is reported retrospectively.
For the purposes of the BER, project commencement is defined as ‘the undertaking of any action, post any design phases, that incurs an expense covered by BER funding’.
As at 31 August 2009, Education Authorities have reported commencements of:
6306 (59%) for Primary Schools for the 21st Century projects and of these, 4 projects have been completed;
10,660 (80%) for National School Pride Program projects and of these, 722 have been completed; and
69 Science and Language Centres for 21st Century Secondary Schools (SLC).
SLC successful projects were announced on 30 June 2009 and the majority of projects are still in the design phase. Under the Guidelines SLC projects are required to commence in August and September.
